details.title: Identifying Mechanisms That Highly Accelerated Tests Miss
details.standardTitle: Identifying Mechanisms That Highly Accelerated Tests Miss

p: Michael J. LuValle born in Cambridge, MA, October 19, 1955, B.A. Mathematics, Pomona College, Claremont, CA, 1977. M.S. statistics, California State University at Hayward, Hayward, CA, 1978, PhD. statistics, University of California Davis, Davis, CA, 1983.

He worked as an Associate Reliability Engineer for three months at Lockheed Missile and Space in the spring of 1979, then was an Assistant Professor in the statistics department at Kansas State University for the 1983–84 academic year before going to AT and T Bell Laboratories in 1984 as an MTS. He served in Bell Laboratories until 2001, when the optical fiber research department became part of OFS Laboratories, where he has remained since.

Dr. LuValle is a member of the American Statistical Association, the Institute for Mathematical Statistics, and the American Association for the Advancement of Science. He was awarded the Wilcoxon Award (jointly with W. Q. Meeker) for best practical application paper in Technometrics in 1995.

details.abstract: Extrapolating reliability from accelerated tests for technologies without field data always carries the risk that the accelerated tests do not show the mechanisms which dominate at operating conditions. In statistical terminology, such accelerated testing carries a risk of confounding. For linear models, there is theory which allows one to determine which models are confounded with others. This paper develops analogous theory for a simple kind of confounding model, evanescent processes, when kinetics is used as the basis of modeling accelerated testing. A heuristic for identifying simple evanescent processes that can give rise to disruptive alternatives (alternative models that reverse the decision which would be made based on modeling to date) is outlined. Then, we develop activity mapping, a tool for quantitatively identifying the parameter values of that evanescent process which can result in disruptive alternatives. Finally, we see how activity mapping can be used to identify experiments which help reveal such disruptive evanescent processes

links.abstract: Stress induced failure of Al-Si metal lines has been observed in long lines less than four microns wide. The failures result from voids or cracks in metal lines and appear very similar to electromigration induced damage. However, these failures can be generated without electrical stress, and are not accelerated by high temperatures. The failures were found to be due to a combination of Coble and Nabarro-Herring creep of the aluminum, and could be prevnted by the addition of 0.5 to 2.0 % copper i...

context.text: Stress voiding in thin aluminum lines in integrated circuits was discovered in the field [1], [2].
Examples mentioned at the beginning, stress voiding, CAF, and optical gratings written in boron doped optical fiber [1]–[7] show that the probability of such confounding is not negligible.

links.abstract: The trend to miniaturize silicon integrated circuits has brought with it a thermal stress-induced void formation problem in the aluminum conductor lines of these circuits. Here, local stress relaxation has been included quantitatively in the construction of a wedge-like void growth model. It is shown that under stress relaxation conditions, the stress-induced grain boundary diffusion equation transforms into the diffusion equation. With the use of appropriate boundary conditions and the initial ...

links.abstract: In papers presented at the 1979 IRPS it was reported that failure of printed-circuit boards due to conductive anodic filaments (CAF) posed a potential reliability problem for applications involving high circuit density, hostile environments and/or low power dissipation. In this paper, the results of a study to characterize the CAF phenomenon with respect to temperature, humidity, applied voltage, and other factors are reported. Further aspects of the mechanism of failure are explored. The result...

context.text: The conductive anodic filament (CAF) failure mode appeared to be a looming disaster for a generation of a particular phone company's switches in the 1970's until researchers identified that the mechanism had a threshold at lower stress below which it did not occur [3]–[6].
This was the case with the CAF failure mode [3]–[6].
Examples mentioned at the beginning, stress voiding, CAF, and optical gratings written in boron doped optical fiber [1]–[3][7] show that the probability of such confounding is not negligible.

context.text: The conductive anodic filament (CAF) failure mode appeared to be a looming disaster for a generation of a particular phone company's switches in the 1970's until researchers identified that the mechanism had a threshold at lower stress below which it did not occur [3]–[5][6].

One way to create a limited failure probability model, where not every experimental unit will fail, (e.g. [17]) is to consider a reversible process driving failure [5], [13] (in the microscopic sense).

Another way to create a model with exactly the same integrated law for constant stress experiments [6], and hence the same behavior in constant stress accelerated tests, is to use the equations [5], [13] .
This was the case with the CAF failure mode [3]–[5][6].
Examples mentioned at the beginning, stress voiding, CAF, and optical gratings written in boron doped optical fiber [1]–[5][7] show that the probability of such confounding is not negligible.

reliability kinetics

links.abstract: Some problems in engineering and applied science require building a model of a newly observed phenomenon and extrapolating that model beyond the regime in which data has been gathered. A simple example is accelerated testing, in which devices are stressed at extreme conditions for a short time — for example, months — in order to build a model of how they behave over decades under moderate stress. In such a situation, choosing the wrong model can cause costly errors in estimating re...

context.text: Gratings written in boron doped silica optical fibers show a secondary relaxation phenomena that could affect the reliability of high precision optical filters over periods of years, but can not be differentiated from the standard relaxation phenomena in short times without specially designed step stress tests [7].

Other empirically observed relations can be derived, for example a power law dependence on absolute temperature falls out if one of the steps in a process corresponds microscopically to a large number of parallel processes with an Arrhenius relation with fixed \$\nu\$, and a distribution of activation energies across the processes [7], [13], [18].
The demarcation approximation [18] for modeling degradation in random media, can be adapted to do both steps for single step parallel thermally driven processes [7], [13].
Examples mentioned at the beginning, stress voiding, CAF, and optical gratings written in boron doped optical fiber [1]–[7] show that the probability of such confounding is not negligible.

context.text: One broadly used model, the accelerated life model, has a direct connection to kinetics [11]–[13].

One way to create a limited failure probability model, where not every experimental unit will fail, (e.g. [17]) is to consider a reversible process driving failure [5], [13] (in the microscopic sense).

Another way to create a model with exactly the same integrated law for constant stress experiments [6], and hence the same behavior in constant stress accelerated tests, is to use the equations [5], [13] .

Other empirically observed relations can be derived, for example a power law dependence on absolute temperature falls out if one of the steps in a process corresponds microscopically to a large number of parallel processes with an Arrhenius relation with fixed \$\nu\$, and a distribution of activation energies across the processes [7], [13], [18].
The demarcation approximation [18] for modeling degradation in random media, can be adapted to do both steps for single step parallel thermally driven processes [7], [13].
In degradation phenomena, sometimes the observable is a linear function of the concentration of the degradation causing reaction products, as in radiation damage to optical fibers ([13] chapter 6).

references.text: M. LuValle, B. Lefevre, S. Kannan, The Design and Analysis of Accelerated Tests for Mission Critical Reliability, 2004, CRC Press Boca Raton.

The Limited Failure Population (LFP) model [17] implies nothing about the effect of stress history on subsequent degradation or failure behavior of an individual device whereas direct kinetic modeling does.

context.text: Other empirically observed relations can be derived, for example a power law dependence on absolute temperature falls out if one of the steps in a process corresponds microscopically to a large number of parallel processes with an Arrhenius relation with fixed \$\nu\$, and a distribution of activation energies across the processes [7], [13], [18].
The demarcation approximation [18] for modeling degradation in random media, can be adapted to do both steps for single step parallel thermally driven processes [7], [13].
The original model, from which demarcation mapping is derived [18], is a model in which there are several active sites in a random media, e.g. a glass, or amorphous film.
The default assumption for the original model [18] is that \$\nu_{1}\$ takes on one value, but there is a distribution of activation energies.

context.text: It is clear from the Stone-Weierstrass theorem [19], that any extrapolation based on fitting a model to data, when that model is drawn from some simple algebra of models without imposed constraints, is subject to the danger of extreme confounding once one leaves the support on which the data are fitted.

context.text: Part of this theory will arise from the work on the variance of extrapolation with a known form of the model started by Elfving [20], and Chernoff [21].

Some of this is contained in classical theory [20], [21], but some remains to be developed in the context of this particular problem, that of extrapolation with evanescent processes representing disruptive alternatives.
